DOC.HEAD: Many Long Distance Phone Rates to Drop in 1990
DOC.TEXT: Many long distance telephone rates to points in the United States and abroad will be going down after the first of the year, the three major long distance companies say. American Telephone and Telegraph Co. filed reductions with the Federal Communications Commission Tuesday. MCI Communications Corp. and U.S. Sprint said they will take action to remain competitive. AT&T says it has about 70 percent of the long distance market, as measured by interstate and intrastate revenues. MCI is No. 2 with more than 10 percent. U.S. Sprint claims 7 to 8 percent. The AT&T reductions will take effect Jan. 1, barring an unusual action by the FCC to block them. The company said the reductions were taken in line with an FCC price cap which has been reduced because local telephone companies are charging long distance companies less for access to customers' lines. AT&T's submission to the FCC called for $300 million a year in reductions on interstate and international long distance services used primarily by residential and small business customers. Other categories of service used by businesses, such as private lines and 800 and 900 numbers, are not affected. MCI spokesman John Hauser said the No. 2 long distance company also will reduce its rates to pass on the savings in local telephone company charges. ``We will remain competitive with them,'' he said. ``I don't know how much our total cost savings will be.'' Hauser's counterpart at U.S. Sprint, Robin Pence, said, ``We are reviewing the filing and we intend to remain competitive.'' The company said price reductions will apply to its ``Reach Out America'' and optional long distance plans as well as to basic long distance service. A 10-minute call during daytime hours on a weekday, to anywhere in the United States, will cost $2.50 or less, a decrease of 1.3 percent on the average, the company said. Some of the increases would be greater. For example, a 10-minute daytime call from Washington to New York, which now costs $2.30, would decline to $2.20. Daytime hours are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. local time Monday through Friday. In the evening, the rate for a call to anywhere in the United States will drop by an average of 2 percent, the company said. An evening call from Washington to San Francisco, Los Angeles or Dallas, which now costs $1.67 for 10 minutes, would be $1.58. The evening period is 5 p.m. to 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday. Weekend rates are in effect all day Saturday and until 5 p.m. on Sunday and the same rates apply from 11 p.m. to 8 a.m. Sunday through Friday. These rates will not change. The maximum for such a call is $1.32 for 10 minutes within the United States, the company said. Discounts for subscribers to the Reach Out America 24-hour plan will be increased from 5 percent to 10 percent on weekday calls and from 20 to 25 percent on evening calls. Under Reach Out America, the evening period is 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. Sunday through Friday. International calls from the U.S. mainland to 25 of the most frequently called countries and overseas areas will be slashed by $104 million. The reductions will vary from country to country and the countries will include Canada, Mexico, Japan, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Israel, Brazil, Australia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Korea. A five-minute call from anywhere in the United States to Japan between 2 and 8 p.m., now $8.72 at the standard rate prevailing in those hours, will drop to $8.07. A similar call to Britain between 1 and 6 p.m., when discount rates are in effect for such calls, will decline from $4.21 to $3.99. Calls to Mexico will decline from 2 to 20 percent, depending on the time and the city from which the call is placed. A five-minute call from New York to Cancun, now $7.90 at the standard rate, will drop to $5.90. Five minutes from Los Angeles to Mexico City, now $6.15, will cost $5.55. AT&T said the reduction will be the company's 10th since 1984 and would bring total rate decreases to 40 percent in the six years since the breakup of the Bell System.
